spanishExample: Andábamos en auto, pero ellos andaban a pie.
englishTranslation: We were riding in the car, but they were walking by foot.
vocabIncluded: a: complement (e.g. ayudar a, empezar a) (preposition)
andaban: walked/went/got along, they walked/went/got along(Andar, imperfect, 3rd person plural)
andábamos: walked/went/got along, we walked/went/got along(Andar, imperfect, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: ¡Regresen! Todavía tenemos ochenta y dos horas.
englishTranslation: (plural) Come back! We still have eighty-two hours.

spanishExample: Andaba en tren y hablaba de negocios cuando sucedió el ataque.
englishTranslation: He was riding the train and talking about business when the attack occurred.
vocabIncluded: andaba: walked/went/got along, he/she/it walked/went/got along(Andar, imperfect, 3rd person)
de used to mean "about", as in "hablar de"
hablaba: was speaking, he/she/it was speaking (Hablar, imperfect, 3rd person)
sucedió: occurred/happened, he/she/it occurred/happened(Suceder, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Yo regresaré en tres días, pero ellos quieren que regreses mañana.
englishTranslation: I’ll return in three days, but they want you to return tomorrow.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
regresaré: will return, I will return (Regresar, future, 1st person)
regreses: return, you return (Regresar, subjunctive, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Anda en auto cuando va a ese lugar, pero regresa a pie.
englishTranslation: He rides the car when he goes to that place, but he returns by foot.
vocabIncluded: a: complement (e.g. ayudar a, empezar a) (preposition)
anda: walks/goes/gets along, he/she/it walks/goes/gets along (Andar, present, 3rd person)
regresa: returns, he/she/it returns (Regresar, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: ¿Por qué andas en auto a la carrera?
englishTranslation: Why do you ride the car to the race?
vocabIncluded: andas: walked/gone/got along, you walked/gone/got along (Andar, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Andamos en tren, pero no sabemos cuándo vamos a regresar.
englishTranslation: We’re riding the train, but we don’t know when we’re going to come back.
vocabIncluded: andamos: walk/go/get along, we walk/go/get along (Andar, present, 1st person plural)
cuándo: adverb meaning "when?" in a question or implied question
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: ¡Regresemos! Hay ochenta y una personas que nos esperan para la sorpresa.
englishTranslation: Let’s go back! There are eighty-one people who await us for the surprise.
vocabIncluded: esperan:  hope/wait/expect, they  hope/wait/expect (Esperar, present, 3rd person plural)
hay: "there is/are" indicating existence (Haber, present, impersonal)
regresemos: let’s go back (Regresar plural imperative)

spanishExample: Por otro lado, regresaste a tiempo para ir a ese negocio.
englishTranslation: On the other hand, you came back on time to go to that business.
vocabIncluded: para: "in order", "in order to" before an infinitive
por otro lado: on the other hand (idiom)
regresaste: returned, you returned (Regresar, preterite, 2nd person)

spanishExample: ¡Regrese aquí! Anduvimos en tren por horas y tenemos que ir a la boda.
englishTranslation: (formal) Come back here! We rode the train for hours and we have to go to the wedding.
vocabIncluded: anduvimos: walked/went/got along, we walked/went/got along (Andar, preterite, 1st person plural)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Para su sorpresa, los nombres de esas personas tienen ochenta y nueve letras.
englishTranslation: To her surprise, the names of those people have eighty-nine letters.
vocabIncluded: para su sorpresa: to someone’s surprise (idiom)

spanishExample: Regresé tarde y no pude ir a la reunión de ese negocio.
englishTranslation: I came back late and couldn’t go to the meeting of that business.
vocabIncluded: pude: "was able / managed", "I was able / managed" (Poder, preterite, 1st person)
regresé: returned, I returned (Regresar, preterite, 1st person)

spanishExample: No puede ir a un lugar cualquiera; tiene ochenta y cuatro años.
englishTranslation: She can’t go to just any place; she’s eighty-four years old.
vocabIncluded: tener X años: to be X years old (idiom)

spanishExample: ¿Por qué andabas en tren con los ochenta y un chicos?
englishTranslation: Why were you riding the train with the eighty-one kids?
vocabIncluded: andabas: walked/went/got along, you walked/went/got along (Andar, imperfect, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Tiene noventa y tres años y no anduvo bien por un tiempo.
englishTranslation: She’s ninety-three years old and she didn’t get along well for a while.
vocabIncluded: "bien": adverb meaning "well", "fine", and a variety of other positive things
anduvo: walked/went/got along, he/she/it walked/went/got along (Andar, preterite, 3rd person)
tener X años: to be X years old (idiom)

spanishExample: ¡Anda a pie! Son solo diez minutos; puedes ir a pie.
englishTranslation: Walk by foot! It’s just ten minutes; you can go by foot.
vocabIncluded: a: complement (e.g. ayudar a, empezar a) (preposition)

spanishExample: Está por demás decir que siempre regresamos a tiempo.
englishTranslation: Needless to say, we always come back on time.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
estar por demás: to be needless/to be superfluous (idiom)
regresamos: return, we return (Regresar, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Regreso porque quiero seguir otra carrera.
englishTranslation: I return because I want to follow another degree program.
vocabIncluded: regreso: return, I return (Regresar, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: ¿Tienes noventa y uno? Creía que tenías noventa y siete.
englishTranslation: You’re ninety-one? I thought you were ninety-seven.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
creía: believed, I believed (Creer, imperfect, 1st person)
tener X años: to be X years old (idiom)

spanishExample: Mi misión es ver los noventa y ocho animales que andan por ahí.
englishTranslation: My mission is to see the ninety-eight animals that are walking around there.
vocabIncluded: andan: walk/go/get along, they walk/go/get along(Andar, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Anduvieron a pie por horas, pero no pudieron ver la pelea.
englishTranslation: They walked by foot for hours, but they couldn’t see the fight.
vocabIncluded: a: complement (e.g. ayudar a, empezar a) (preposition)
anduvieron: walked/went/got along, they walked/went/got along (Andar, preterite, 3rd person plural)
pudieron: "were able / managed", "they were able / managed" (Poder, preterite, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Quiere que regrese pronto, pero mi carrera viene primero.
englishTranslation: She wants me to come back soon, but my career comes first.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
regrese: return, I return (Regresar, subjunctive, 1st person)

spanishExample: ¡Regresa! Sabes que fue un error y que vas a tener éxito.
englishTranslation: Come back! You know it was a mistake and that you’ll be successful.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Está andando en auto todavía; por eso no regresó.
englishTranslation: He’s still riding the car; that’s why he didn’t return.
vocabIncluded: regresó: returned, he/she/it returned (Regresar, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Vamos a andar en auto y escuchar esa canción como noventa y seis veces.
englishTranslation: We’re going to ride the car and listen to that song like ninety-six times.
vocabIncluded: andar: to walk / to go/get along (Andar infinitive)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Tuvo un accidente cuando escuchaba música y todavía no ha regresado.
englishTranslation: He had an accident when he was listening to music and he still hasn't returned.
vocabIncluded: ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: ¡No regreses nunca! No quiero que ni tú ni tus amigos regresen.
englishTranslation: Don’t ever come back! I don't want either you or your friends (m) to come back.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
regresen: return, they return (Regresar, subjunctive, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Andaba en auto porque quería ver a las ochenta y cinco personas.
englishTranslation: I was riding the car because I wanted to see the eighty-five people.
vocabIncluded: "the personal a": using an extra "a" before a direct object when it's a person
andaba: walked/went/got along, I walked/went/got along (Andar, imperfect, 1st person)

spanishExample: ¿A qué hora regresas? Tengo un problema con mi pie y no puedo ir solo.
englishTranslation: What time are you coming back? I have a problem with my foot and can’t go alone.
vocabIncluded: regresas: return, you return (Regresar, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Él es el único que está de pie porque ya terminó su tarea.
englishTranslation: He’s the only one standing because he already finished his homework.
vocabIncluded: terminó: ended/finished, he/she/it ended/finished (Terminar, preterite, 3rd person)
ya: adverb meaning "anymore", "already", and a variety of other time-related things

spanishExample: Quiero que regrese pronto, pero sé que regresará en un mes.
englishTranslation: I want her to return soon, but I know she'll return in a month.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
regresará: will return, he/she/it will return (Regresar, future, 3rd person)
regrese: return, he/she/it return (Regresar, subjunctive, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Nos iba a ayudar con nuestro proyecto, así que regresamos ahí.
englishTranslation: He was going to help us with our project, so we returned there.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
iba: "was going", "he/she/it was going" (Ir, imperfect, 3rd person)
regresamos: returned, we returned (Regresar, preterite, 1st person plural)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: ¿Anduviste bien? Yo anduve mal.
englishTranslation: Did you get along well? I got along badly.
vocabIncluded: "bien": adverb meaning "well", "fine", and a variety of other positive things
anduve: walked/went/got along, I walked/went/got along (Andar, preterite, 1st person)
anduviste: walked/went/got along, you walked/went/got along (Andar, preterite, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Escucho esa canción cuando ando en auto, pero no entiendo la letra.
englishTranslation: I listen to that song when I ride the car, but I don’t understand the lyrics.
vocabIncluded: ando: walk/go/get along, I walk/go/get along (Andar, present, 1st person)
entiendo: understand, I understand (Entender, present, 1st person)
